Think not, good Sir, the muses lay,</br>Shall unregarded pass away,</br>Like Cibber's birth-day odes;</br>Supported by th' inspiring power,</br>Above the vulgar tribe she'll soar,</br>Immortal, as the gods.

Tho' Spencer's praise is still compleat,</br>And Milton claims the highest seat,</br>Among the sons of fame;</br>The world shall honour Dryden's verse,</br>And Pope's delightful strains rehearse,</br>While flows the silver Thame.

Old Chaucer in a barb'rous age,</br>Warm with a true poetic rage,</br>Could over time prevail,</br>And ev'ry Wiltshire swain shall praise,</br>The bard who made well-meaning lays,</br>And sung them to his flail.

Mira still shines in Granvil's lays,</br>And Sacharissa's pride and praise,</br>In Waller's page shall last;</br>While many an equal beauteous dame,</br>Without a bard to sing her name,</br>Into oblivion's cast.

Immortal Marlbro' and Eugene,</br>The hero's of great Anna's reign,</br>Were hero's not alone;</br>The world would other chiefs revere,</br>Did poets in their cause appear,</br>To make their merits known.

When resting in the silent grave,</br>What differ cowards from the brave,</br>Except the voice of fame?</br>O gen'rous Townshend, then excuse</br>The efforts of a grateful muse</br>To celebrate thy name.

When Britain's int'rest calls to war,</br>You draw the sword, devoid of fear,</br>Intrepid, yet serene;</br>Not vainly rais'd amid success,</br>Not meanly drooping with distress,</br>You keep the golden mean.

A foe declar'd to fraud and guile,</br>And bribes (the bane of Britain's isle!)</br>You, like a patriot stand,</br>Rewarding worth where'er it lies,</br>And combat knavery and vice,</br>With an unsparing hand.

The master of a vast estate,</br>Who prides himself in heaps of plate,</br>Is not compleatly blest;</br>But he who freely from his store,</br>Relieves the stranger and the poor,</br>And gives the aged rest.

Who honour more, than life, esteems,</br>And worse than death or bondage deems,</br>Detraction and deceit,</br>By virtue bound his blood will spend,</br>To serve his country or his friend,</br>That man is truly great.</br>
